awd_titl_txt: Pathways to STEM: Kansas Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the KS-LSAMP project was to build a pathway to lead students to STEM baccalaureate degrees at Kansas State University (KSU) and in so doing, double the number of underrepresented minorities graduating with STEM degrees within the five years of the original project timeline (2013-2018). To this end, the project team at KSU

1)      Worked with the leadership and STEM departments of four Kansas Minority Serving Institutions with 2-year transferable programs to establish partnerships;

2)      Worked together with those partners to develop innovative and culturally appropriate recruitment materials and activities for high schools and college STEM programs;

3)      Developed and evaluated systematic approaches to assuring successful transfer to K-State or other Kansas 4-year institutions with high quality science and engineering programs;

4)      Developed or improved academic, curricular and co-curricular activities known to impact persistence and retention of URM students at 2- and 4-year partner institutions and at KSU, including special focus on critical pathway junctures (e.g., advising, financial assistance, campus integration); and

5)      Worked with our evaluator to develop formative evaluation that assured continuous project improvement and to conduct summative evaluation to describe the results and impact of the project on students and institutions, including development of a longitudinal tracking system to monitor progress, especially at critical junctures in the pathway.

Intellectual Merit: The project design was grounded in educational theories including retention/integration, cumulative advantage, engagement, and constructivism. It incorporated established best practices for working with URM students such as STEM identity formation through experiential programs including student research and internships, a focus on critical junctures including the first year and post-transfer year, training of faculty and staff to enhance cultural competency, and building of academic integration and STEM self-efficacy. An extensive evaluation plan designed around a logic model was used as the basis for project assessment.

Broader Impacts: The overall goal of the project was to double the number of URM STEM baccalaureate degrees conferred by KSU. This goal was achieved in project year four; the numbers are continuing to increase. In building the infrastructure in support of the goal at participating Alliance institutions, the capacity of all partners was enhanced; communication and coordination to facilitate the success of transfer students was embedded in the culture of the partners; and other populations not currently well represented in STEM disciplines such as women, first-generation-to-college, and military-associated students should benefit in the future. In addition, best practices developed at KS-LSAMP partner institutions were disseminated to other KS institutions as well as nationally.
